questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with worsening shortness of breath and fatigue. An echocardiogram shows left ventricular dilation and significant aortic regurgitation. Which of the following are the possible conditions causing Aortic regurgitation? Ankylosing Spondylitis Aortic Dissection Marfan's Syndrome Syphilis
questions.explanation:
Aortic Regurgitation

Aetiology

Conditions affecting the valve structure and its functions

Conditions causing valve root dilatation
  • Bicuspid Aortic valve (Congenital)
  • Infective Endocarditis
  • Rheumatic fever
  • Myxomatous prolapse of the valve
  • Scarring of the valve by Syphilis (statement 4)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis (statement 1)
  • Radiation
  • Trauma
  • Aortic Dissection (statement 2)
  • Aortitis (Takayasu arteritis or GCA)
  • Hypertension
  • Marfan syndrome (statement 3)
  • Medial Degeneration
  • Nonsyndromic familial aneurysm

Pathophysiology

Clinical symptoms
  • Usually, it starts appearing only after 10 to 15 years.
  • Symptoms specific to AR:
    • Palpitations (more in the supine position)
    • Head pounding sensation
  • Other symptoms:
    • Paroxysmal Nocturnal dyspnea (sometimes the early one to appear)
    • Angina on rest or exertion & breathlessness on exertion
    • Orthopnea and diaphoresis
    • Peripheral edema

questions.text: Match the following murmurs with the respective conditions. S.No Murmur Condition 1) a) Mitral Stenosis 2) b) Aortic Stenosis 3) c) Mitral Regurgitation 4) d) Aortic Regurgitation
questions.explanation:
Aortic Stenosis:

  • Crescendo-decrescendo ejection murmur

Mitral/Tricuspid Regurgitation:

  • Holosystolic, high-pitched “blowing” murmur

Aortic Regurgitation:

  • Early diastolic, decrescendo, high-pitched “blowing” murmur

Mitral Stenosis:

  • Delayed rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur with opening snap

Mitral valve prolapse:

  • Late crescendo murmur with mid systolic click (MC) that occurs after carotid pulse

Ventricular septal defect:

  • Holosystolic, harsh-sounding murmur

questions.text: A 25 y/o patient with h/o pulmonary hypertension presents with exertional dyspnea. You auscultate a high-pitched, decrescendo diastolic murmur at the second left intercostal space, radiating along the left sternal border that increases with inspiration. Which of the following murmurs is this?

A 65-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of left arm pain and intermittent dizziness. O/E, you find a notable difference in blood pressure readings: 150/90 mmHg in the right arm and 100/60 mmHg in the left arm. Which condition is least likely to cause this variation?

Match the following cardiac valvular disorders with their specific murmur type: Valvular defect Murmur 1. Aortic stenosis a. Pansystolic murmur increasing with inspiration 2. Mitral regurgitation b. Mid-diastolic rumble with opening snap 3. Mitral stenosis c. Harsh systolic murmur radiating to the carotids 4. Tricuspid regurgitation d. Holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla
questions.explanation:
Valvular disease

Most common cause

ECG findings

JVP findings

Type of murmur

Specific features

Mitral regurgitation

  • Rheumatic heart disease
  • Degenerative
  • Atrial fibrillation may be present
  • P-mitrale > 120 seconds (enlarged left atrium)



 

Changes are seen only in advanced cases.

Holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla.
  • Wide variable splitting of S2
  • A2 appears early as less blood is flowing through the aortic valve; thus, the S2 split is wide

Mitral stenosis

Rheumatic heart disease

Right axis deviation

RV hypertrophy.

Mid-diastolic rumble with an opening snap.

Loud S1

Malar rash

Distended neck veins

Tricuspid stenosis

Rheumatic

(coexist with mitral stenosis)

  

Tall P waves in the lead II

Right axis deviation

Large ‘a’ wave

Blunted ‘y’ wave

Mid-diastolic murmur

Carvallo’s sign

Tricuspid regurgitation

Rheumatic

‘C-v’ wave

Steep ‘y’ descent

Blowing holosystolic murmur

Systolic liver pulsation

 

Carvallo’s sign

Aortic regurgitation

  • Infective endocarditis
  • Bicuspid aortic valve

Left axis deviation

LV hypertrophy

Changes are seen only in advanced cases

Decrescendo diastolic murmur
  • Wide pulse pressure
  • Water hammer pulse
 

Aortic stenosis

Degenerative calcification

53% of cases have congenital bicuspid aortic valve

Accentuated “a” wave due to reduced RV cavity distensibility from the hypertrophied interventricular septum

Crescendo-decrescendo ejection murmur.

Gallavardin effect

Pulmonary regurgitation

Pulmonary hypertension

  

Right axis deviation

RV hypertrophy.

  

Large ‘a’ wave

End–diastolic murmur

(Graham Steel murmur)

Cardiac MRI is the IOC rather than echocardiography

Pulmonary stenosis

Congenital defect

Systolic ejection murmur

Wide split S2

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl with a history of Tetralogy of Fallot repair 12 months ago presents with abdominal swelling and pedal oedema. Cardiac auscultation reveals an early diastolic murmur, and ECG shows right ventricular and atrial enlargement. Considering the suspicion of pulmonary regurgitation, which investigation is most appropriate for further evaluation?
questions.explanation:
PULMONARY REGURGITATION

Aetiology

  • Pulmonary artery hypertension - annular dilatation of the pulmonary valve
  • Post-repair of Tetralogy of Fallot
  • Post balloon valvotomy
  • Marfan syndrome

Pathophysiology

  • Severe pulmonary regurgitation (PR) results in right ventricular enlargement and eccentric hypertrophy due to increased preload and afterload.
  • A reverse pressure gradient from the pulmonary artery to the right ventricle drives the regurgitation, leading to a reduction in cardiac output over time.
  • As the condition progresses, right atrial involvement may occur, elevating jugular venous pressure.

Clinical features

  • Fatigue, dyspnea, ascites, and pedal oedema
  • Auscultation reveals an early diastolic murmur (Graham steel murmur)

Investigations

  • Chest X-ray: Enlarged right atrium and ventricular shadow
  • Cardiac MRI: Investigation of choice, especially in patients with repaired congenital heart defects.
  • Echocardiography (transthoracic): It helps assess pulmonary valve morphology and the direction of blood flow. (Option A and C)
  • Cardiac catheterisation is not usually done but can be done during transcatheter pulmonary valve procedures. (Option D)

Treatment

  • Medical: Diuretics for symptoms of right-sided heart failure
  • Surgical: Transcatheter pulmonic valve replacement.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents with exercise intolerance and occasional chest pain. Examination reveals a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and elevated jugular venous pressure. An echocardiogram shows a peak systolic gradient of 70 mmHg across the pulmonary valve, raising suspicion for pulmonary valve stenosis. Which of the following set of statements is true regarding this condition? Pulmonic stenosis is always congenital. Dysplastic valves leading to pulmonary stenosis are seen in Noonan syndrome. Severe PS is defined by peak systolic gradient across the PV>64 mmHg Percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty is indicated for all patients. Pulmonic stenosis usually leads to right ventricular hypertrophy.
questions.explanation:
PULMONARY STENOSIS

Aetiology

It is essentially a congenital disease, but it may be acquired (Statement 1 ruled out)

  • Noonan syndrome (dysplastic pulmonary valve) (Statement 2)
  • Tetralogy of Fallot
  • Carcinoids
  • Bulky vegetation or tumours

Pathophysiology

  • Pulmonary stenosis obstructs blood flow from the right ventricle, resulting in increased chamber pressure and subsequent right ventricular hypertrophy. (Statement 5)
  • Right ventricular dysfunction occurs early and at lower pressures due to its reduced adaptability to hemodynamic burden compared to the left ventricle.

Severity

Defined by the systolic pressure gradient between the RV and PA

  • Severe: Peak systolic gradient >64 mm hg (Statement 3)
  • Moderate: Peak systolic gradient 36-64 mm hg
  • Mild: Peak systolic gradient <36 hh mg

Clinical features

  • Mild to moderate PS are asymptomatic.
  • Severe PS: Exertional dyspnea, fatigue, anginal pain and systemic venous congestion
  • Syncope may occur during stress.
  • Auscultation: Mid-systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur preceded by an ejection click.
  • JVP: Prominent ‘a’ wave

Investigations

  • ECG: Right axis deviation + Right ventricular hypertrophy
  • Chest X-ray: Post-stenotic dilation of the main PA and RV enlargement.
  • Echocardiography:
    • Transthoracic: Helps assess jet velocity, gradients, ventricular function
    • Transesophageal (for detailed assessment of RV outflow tract)

Management

  • Medical: Diuretics for symptoms of right-sided heart failure
  • Surgical: Percutaneous pulmonary balloon valvuloplasty (Statement 4 ruled out) is done when
    • Symptomatic patients with moderate to severe PS
    • Asymptomatic patients with peak gradient >64 mmHg or mean gradient > 35 mmHg.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of long-standing hypertension and atrial fibrillation presents with progressive fatigue & bilateral leg swelling. O/E, the patient has distended neck veins with the following waveform with a blowing holosystolic murmur that increases with inspiration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
TRICUSPID REGURGITATION

Aetiology

  • Primary (organic)
    • Rheumatic disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Myxomatous - tricuspid valve prolapse
    • Carcinoid
    • Radiation
    • Congenital (Ebstein’s anomaly)
    • Trauma
    • Myocardial infarction (Papillary muscle rupture)
 
  • Secondary (functional)
    • Long-standing pulmonary hypertension
    • Left-sided heart disease
    • Cardiomyopathy
    • Atrial fibrillation - functional tricuspid regurgitation
    • Chronic RV apical pacing (dyssynchrony)

Pathophysiology

  • An incompetent tricuspid valve allows blood to flow back from the right ventricle (RV) into the right atrium (RA) during systole, increasing RA and jugular venous pressures, seen as prominent C-V waves.
  • Severe TR causes ventricularization of the RA waveform and RA dilation, resulting in reduced cardiac output that does not improve with exercise.

Clinical features

  • Features of right-sided heart failure
    • Distended neck veins
    • Hepatomegaly
    • Ascites
    • Edema
    • Positive hepatojugular reflex
    • Pulsatile liver (Systolic pulsation)
  • Auscultation: Blowing holosystolic murmur along the lower left sternal border, which intensifies with inspiration (Carvallo’s sign)

Investigations

  • Chest X-ray: Right atrial and right ventricular enlargement seen.
  • ECG: Tall P waves in lead II (RA enlargement) and Right axis deviation.
  • Echocardiogram (Gold standard)
    • Right atrial and ventricular dilation.
    • Tricuspid valve annular dilation.
    • Regurgitant jet from RV to RA on Doppler imaging.

Management

  • Medical therapy :
    • Diuretics are used to manage the symptoms of right-sided heart failure
    • Aldosterone antagonists may be added in cases of significant volume overload.
  • Surgical intervention: Tricuspid valve repair or replacement may be considered for patients with severe TR

questions.text: A 66-year-old female presents with fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and swelling in her legs. On examination, she has jugular venous distention with giant ‘a’ waves, hepatomegaly, and ascites. Auscultation reveals a diastolic murmur at the lower left sternal border, which increases in intensity with inspiration. What’s the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
TRICUSPID STENOSIS

Aetiology

  • Congenital
  • Rheumatic origin (often coexists with mitral stenosis)

Pathophysiology

  • RA pressure ↑ , due to the diastolic pressure gradient between RA and RV, results in systemic venous congestion.
  • Restricted forward flow of blood leads to ↓ cardiac output.

Clinical features

  • Fatigue
  • Mild dyspnea
  • Venous congestion (right-side heart failure): Hepatomegaly, ascites, oedema and may lead to cardiac cirrhosis.
  • Physical examination:
    • Jugular venous distension with prominent ‘a’ waves
    • Auscultation: Mid-diastolic murmur at left lower sternal border
    • Murmur increases with inspiration (Carvallo's sign).
  • If mitral stenosis coexist
    • Pulmonary artery hypertension
    • Orthopnea due to pulmonary oedema

Investigations

  • Chest X-ray and ECG show features of RA enlargement
  • Echocardiogram: Thickened tricuspid valve with diastolic doming and increased pressure gradient between RV and RA.

Management

  • Medical management: To reduce systemic venous congestion symptoms
    • Dietary salt restriction
    • Loop diuretics
  • Surgical intervention: Valvular repair or Prosthetic valve replacement.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man presents with severe aortic regurgitation. He reports increasing fatigue, breathlessness, and episodes of dizziness. On auscultation, a diastolic murmur is heard along with a water-hammer pulse, and an echocardiogram shows significant left ventricular dilation and an ejection fraction of 55%. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Investigations

Findings

ECG
  • LV Hypertrophy
  • Left axis deviation is noted
  • QRS prolongation is seen occasionally
  • LV Strain - ST wave depression and T wave inversion in I, aVL, V5, V6 leads

Chest X-ray
  • Inferolateral displacement of the apex is noted
  • Aortic root dilation, often associated with aortic regurgitation, can be visible on a lateral chest X-ray as it fills the retrosternal space.
  • It is not very sensitive to Aortic root conditions

Echocardiogram
  • Rapid fluttering of the anterior mitral valve during diastole because of the regurgitation.
  • A dilated left ventricle is noted.
  • It is the investigation of choice in Severe AR

Cardiac Catheterization and Angiography

(Occasionally done)
  • To evaluate the LV function and regurgitation
  • Done before surgery, but CT angiography can be done instead.

Management

Type

Acute AR

Chronic AR

Medical

(Option A)
  • IV Diuretics (Furosemide) and Vasodilators (Sodium Nitroprusside) are used to stabilise the patient.
  • Beta Blockers are contraindicated as they worsen the symptoms and reduce the cardiac output.
  • Diuretics and Vasodilators like
    • ACEi, CCB,
    • Hydralazine,
    • ARBs (can be used in chronic AR) to manage HTN; Target SBP <140 mm/Hg.
  • For Angina: Nitrates
  • For Syphilis: Benzathine Penicillin, 2.4 million units IM, three doses given with one week gap.

Surgical

  • Aortic valve replacement (AVR) is the treatment of choice, usually within 24 hours of diagnosis.
  • Intra-Aortic Balloon pump is contraindicated as it worsens the regurgitant flow. (Option C)
  • AVR is indicated when developing LV dysfunction or symptoms.
  • Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (Option B) is not suggested due to its limited success in chronic conditions.

questions.text: Match the following signs with specific features Signs Features 1. Muller Sign a) Systolic pulsations of the Spleen 2. Rosenbach sign b) Visible systolic pulsation of the uvula 3. Gerhardt's sign c) Jarring motion of the head with each heartbeat 4. De-Musset sign d) Systolic pulsations of the Liver
questions.explanation:
Signs of Aortic Regurgitation

Muller Sign

It is a visible systolic pulsation of the uvula

Rosenbach sign

Systolic pulsations of the Liver

Gerhardt's sign

Systolic pulsations of the Spleen

Quincke's sign

Repeatedly alternating blushing and blanching of capillaries in the nail folds upon palpation (Capillary Pulsations)

Landolphi sign

Alternating systolic constriction and diastolic dilatation of pupils

Traube Sign

It is pistol shot sounds that are heard while auscultating over the femoral artery.

Water-Hammer pulse

Strong pulse that rises quickly and then drops off suddenly.

Duroziez Sign

It is a to-and-fro murmur heard while auscultating the femoral artery.

De-Musset sign

The jarring motion of the head with each heartbeat

Examination Findings of Aortic Regurgitation

Blood Pressure
  • Elevated systolic pressure and decreased diastolic pressure result in increased arterial pulse pressure.
  • Atrio-ventricular malformation and Atrio-ventricular ﬁstula also show low diastolic BP due to continuous Korotkoﬀ sounds.
  • Positive Hill’s sign is an abnormal difference in BP in the upper limb and lower limb.

On Palpation
  • Heaving LV impulse is noted, which is displaced laterally and inferiorly
  • Diastolic and Systolic Thrills were noticed at the left lower sternal border and suprasternal notch, respectively.

On Auscultation

  

Heart Sounds
  • A2 is absent
  • In the Bicuspid aortic valve, systolic ejection sound is present
  • Sometimes, A4 is also heard

Murmurs
  • A Decrescendo diastolic murmur, best heard when sitting up and leaning forward, is an early diastolic murmur that becomes holo-diastolic as the condition progresses to a severe stage.
  • Musical diastolic murmur is aortic cusp fluttering in the regurgitant flow.
  • Mid-diastolic murmur
  • Austin Flint murmur is a soft, low-pitched, mid- to end-diastolic murmur caused by mitral valve displacement due to AR.
  • Ejection systolic murmur is commonly heard in AR along with AS.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male with a two-year history of severe aortic regurgitation presents with complaints of worsening dyspnea, angina and orthopnea. Physical examination reveals a loud diastolic murmur at the left sternal border and a widened pulse pressure. An echocardiogram indicates significant left ventricular dilation. What is the likely estimated regurgitant volume in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Echocardiogram Findings for Aortic Regurgitation

Severe Aortic regurgitation

Progressive Aortic regurgitation
  • Regurgitant Volume is > 60 ml/beat
  • Regurgitant fraction is ≥50%
  • Holodiastolic aortic flow reversal - blood flows backwards into the left ventricle throughout the diastolic phase.
  • Diastolic flow reversal in the descending aorta.
  • Ejection Fraction is 55 - 60 %
  • Left ventricle end-systolic dimension (LVESD) is >50 mm
  • Left ventricle end-diastolic dimension

(LVEDD) is > 65 mm

Acute Aortic Regurgitation

Chronic Aortic Regurgitation
  • It is a sudden onset of significant backflow from the aorta into the left ventricle, causing LV dilatation.
  • This leads to pulmonary oedema, which can progress to acute heart failure.
  • The presence of a water-hammer pulse/Corrigan’s pulse is a strong pulse that rises quickly and then drops off suddenly.
  • Quincke's pulse (Capillary pulsations)
  • The Frank-Starling law explains that blood flowing back into the left ventricle increases its contractions due to stretching of the ventricle walls.
  • Reduced Cardiac output at rest.
  • Both Preload and Afterload are increased (Laplace law)
  • LVH is common.
  • High myocardial oxygen demand can lead to Myocardial ischemia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with intermittent palpitations, chest discomfort, and fatigue. A mid-systolic click and late systolic murmur are heard at the apex. Echocardiography shows mitral valve leaflets billowing into the left atrium during systole. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiology of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Inflammation of the mitral valve due to rheumatic fever

options.label: B
options.text: Fibrotic changes affecting the mitral valves

options.label: C
options.text: Rupture of the tendinae of the mitral valve

options.label: D
options.text: Myxomatous degeneration of mitral valve apparatus.

questions.correct_answer: D. Myxomatous degeneration of mitral valve apparatus.
questions.explanation:
MITRAL VALVE PROLAPSE

Aetiology

  • Most cases are idiopathic
  • Myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve apparatus (Reduced type III collagen production)
  • Marfan syndrome (Fibrillin-1 protein defect)
  • Ehler Danlos syndrome
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Straight back syndrome (reduced thoracic kyphosis) compresses the heart between the sternum and vertebrae, altering its position and increasing the likelihood of mitral valve prolapse (MVP).

Pathophysiology

mitral valve prolapse" data-author="" data-hash="8847" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" height="230" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/zNqtoziid3ggvNttuHvn1744309432.png" width="462" />

Clinical features

  • Incidence
    • More in females: 15-30 years
    • Males: 50 years
  • Severity: More severe in men than women
  • Symptoms:
    • Initially asymptomatic
    • Palpitation and syncope due to premature ventricular contraction.
    • Atypical features
      • Substernal pain without exertion.
      • Transient ischemic attack.
      • Risk of endocarditis and Sudden cardiac death.
      • If Mitral regurgitation (MR) occurs, it can lead to increased pressure in the lungs, causing frank pulmonary oedema.

Condition

Valsalva or Sudden Standing

Squatting, Leg Raising, Standing to Supine, Isometric Exercises

Preload and Afterload

↓

↑

Cavity size

↓

↑

Chordae tendineae stretching

↓

↑

Timing of click

The click occurs earlier, closer to S1

The click occurs later, away from S1

Murmur duration

↑

↓

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman reports experiencing mild chest pain and shortness of breath on exertion. Upon examination, a prominent ejection-type systolic murmur is noted, best heard at the right second intercostal space and radiating to the carotids. An Echocardiogram shows an aortic valve area of 0.9 cm², and ECG reveals Left ventricular hypertrophy. Which stage of aortic stenosis is suspected, and what is the ideal management? (TAVR: Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement)
questions.explanation:
Stage

Aortic Valve area

Explanation

Stage A

Normal

Patient with normal aortic valve functioning and presence of risk factors like:

  • Old age
  • Congenital valvular disease
  • History of rheumatic fever
  • History of endocarditis
  • Genetic Polymorphisms
  • HTN, DM, CKD, Smoking & High LDL.
 

Stage B

1.5 - 2 cm² (Mild)

It involves asymptomatic patients with mild to moderate stenosis.

1 - 1.5 cm² (Moderate)

Stage C

< 1 cm²

Asymptomatic severe aortic stenosis

Stage D

< 1 cm²

Symptomatic severe aortic stenosis

Stage/Condition

Management

Asymptomatic with HTN or CAD

Start ACE inhibitors or beta-blockers.

Stage B
  • Consider TAVR if LVEF < 60% (based on three readings).
  • Regular monitoring with Doppler echocardiogram every 1-2 years to evaluate progression.

Stage C
  • Avoid strenuous exercise, hypovolemia, and dehydration to maintain adequate cardiac output.
  • Indications for TAVR:
    • LVEF < 50%.
    • Ejection velocity > 5 m/sec.
    • Transvalvular gradient (LV-AO) > 60 mmHg.
  • Statins should be started to prevent the progression of atherosclerosis.

Stage D
  • TAVR is indicated.
  • For pediatric patients with congenital aortic stenosis, aortic balloon valvuloplasty is the preferred treatment.

Patients in Stage B and Stage C are monitored regularly with Doppler echocardiograms every 1 to 2 years to assess disease progression.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient presents with angina and shortness of breath on exertion. Physical examination reveals a slow-rising carotid pulse and a systolic ejection murmur. An echocardiogram shows thickened and calcified aortic valve leaflets with reduced opening. Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed on the ECG in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Heart Rate
  • Generally regular until late stages.
  • Atrial fibrillation (AF) may indicate associated mitral valve disease

Blood Pressure
  • It is commonly elevated in older adults with aortic stenosis (AS).
  • In late stages, stroke volume declines, leading to potential systolic pressure drop and narrowed pulse pressure.

Carotid Pulse
  • Characterized by a slow rise and delayed peak (pulsus parvus et tardus/Anacrotic pulse)

  • A thrill or anacrotic “shudder” may be felt over the carotid arteries, often more prominent on the left

JVP
  • Accentuated “a” wave due to reduced right ventricular (RV) cavity distensibility from the hypertrophied interventricular septum.

LV Impulse
  • Lateral displacement in advanced stages.
  • A double apical impulse and palpable S4 may be noted, especially in the left lateral recumbent position.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents to the clinic with increasing fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. O/E a harsh, systolic crescendo-decrescendo ejection murmur is noted at the right second intercostal space. Which of the following symptoms is not part of the classic triad associated with this condition?

A 72-year-old woman presents with fatigue and progressive shortness of breath, particularly when climbing stairs. During the physical examination, a harsh, systolic ejection murmur is heard at the right second intercostal space, radiating to the carotids. Which of the following factors is least likely to be associated with the development of the condition?
questions.explanation:
Degenerative Calcification

The primary cause of aortic stenosis (AS) in adults, often due to:

  • Congenital Bicuspid Aortic Valve (BAV): Approximately 53% of cases.
  • Trileaflet Valve Deterioration
  • Previous Rheumatic Fever (Option C ruled out): Inflammation can lead to scarring and calcification.

Rheumatic Heart Disease 

It causes commissural fusion, resembling BAV, and leads to valve narrowing.

Mediastinal Radiation (Option A ruled out)

Cause late scarring and calcification of the aortic leaflets.

Shone Complex

Components include Aortic stenosis, Coarctation of aorta, Parachute mitral valve, supravalvular mitral membrane

Genetic polymorphisms
  • Vitamin D receptor
  • Estrogen receptor (notably in postmenopausal women)
  • Interleukin 10
  • Apolipoprotein E4

Traditional risk factors

Hypertension, High LDL, Smoking, DM, CKD

Bicuspid Aortic Valve Disease
  • Most common congenital heart valve defect, with a male predominance (2–4:1).
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant with incomplete penetrance
  • Genetic Factors: Mutations in NOTCH1 (Option B ruled out), GATA5, and GATA4 have been noted

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with exertional dyspnea and a prominent heart murmur. Upon auscultation, the murmur is best heard at the right second intercostal space and radiates to the carotids. Interestingly, the murmur also becomes higher-pitched when heard at the apex. What is the most likely diagnosis associated with this auscultatory finding?

A 60-year-old female patient presents with exertional dyspnea and a history of rheumatic fever. An echocardiogram shows isolated mitral stenosis with a calcified valve. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for her condition?
questions.correct_answer: C. Schedule for mitral valve replacement
questions.explanation:
Procedure

Indications / Requirements

Mitral Balloon Valvuloplasty (PMBC) (Option B ruled out)
  • Significant symptoms present
  • Isolated mitral stenosis (no or trivial mitral regurgitation)
  • Mobile, non-calcified valve/sub valve apparatus on echocardiogram
  • Left atrium free of thrombus

Surgical Commissurotomy
  • Required if PMBC fails
  • Involves opening valve commissures and addressing subvalvular structures

Mitral Valve Replacement (Option C)
  • Substantial mitral regurgitation
  • Rigid and calcified valve
  • Presence of thrombus formation

questions.text: A 48-year-old female presents with worsening exertional dyspnea and fatigue. She has a history of rheumatic fever during her childhood. O/E, you note a diastolic murmur at the cardiac apex, along with a pronounced opening snap. Which of the following findings is least likely to be present?

A 62-year-old female with a history of rheumatic heart disease comes to the OPD for a regular follow-up. Echocardiography confirmed the presence of severe mitral regurgitation (MR). When considering her treatment options, which of the following interventions should not be included in her management plan?

options.label: A
options.text: Use of Apixaban if her CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2

options.label: C
options.text: Mitral valve repair if ejection fraction falls less than 60%

questions.correct_answer: A. Use of Apixaban if her CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2
questions.explanation:
Management of Mitral Regurgitation

Investigations

  • ECG
    • Atrial fibrillation may be present in cases of chronic MR
    • P-mitrale > 120 seconds (enlarged left atrium)
  • Echocardiogram
    • Regurgitant flow of blood from the left ventricle to the left atrium
  • Chest X-ray
    • Double atrial shadow (left atrium enlarged)
    • Walking man sign (↑ carinal angle)
    • Signs of pulmonary oedema: Pulmonary congestion and Kerley B lines.
    • Left ventricular dilatation due to volume overload
      • (MS, there is compensatory hypertrophy)

Treatment

  • Acute MR leading to decompensated heart failure can be treated with:
    • Loop diuretics
    • Sodium nitroprusside
    • Mechanical support till surgical repair
  • Chronic MR
    • For secondary MR, aggressive guideline-directed therapy (GDMT) can be done using.
      • Beta-blockers (Atenolol and Metoprolol)
      • ACE inhibitors (Lisinopril and Captopril)
      • Angiotensin receptor blockers (Telmisartan and Losartan)
      • Cardiac resynchronization therapy for arrhythmias (Option B ruled out)
    • Warfarin or NOAC if atrial fibrillation occurs
      • NOAC should be avoided in the presence of rheumatic heart disease and mechanical prosthetic valves (Option A)
      • Warfarin is preferred in RHD with valvular atrial fibrillation (Option D ruled out)
    • Surgical repair:
      • Mitral valve repair > replacement
      • Transcatheter mitral valve repair (Mitra clip)
    • Surgical repair in asymptomatic patients must be done when EF<60% or LV ESD >= 40mm. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, shortness of breath on exertion, and palpitations. On physical examination, a systolic thrill is palpable at the cardiac apex. Echocardiography showed severe backflow of blood from the left ventricle to the left atrium during ventricular systole. What kind of murmur is most likely to be heard during cardiac auscultation of this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: An opening snap followed by a diastolic murmur

options.label: C
options.text: Holosystolic murmur, best heard at the apex

options.label: D
options.text: Crescendo decrescendo systolic murmur best heard at the base

questions.correct_answer: C. Holosystolic murmur, best heard at the apex
questions.explanation:
MITRAL REGURGITATION

Clinical examination

  • BP may be normal or ↓ ; Narrow pulse pressure.
  • Palpable thrill at the cardiac apex.
  • Hyperdynamic and laterally displaced apex beat.
  • Normal or ↑ JVP.

Auscultation findings

  • Soft or absent S1.
  • Wide variable splitting of S2: P2 is variable, and A2 appears early as less blood flows through the aortic valve; thus, the S2 split is wide.
  • S4 may be heard in acute severe MR.

Murmur
  • Holosystolic murmur in chronic MR. (High-pitched blowing murmur, radiating towards axilla)
  • A decrescendo early systolic murmur in acute severe MR.

Mitral Regurgitation

Clinical Findings

Auscultation Findings

Murmur
  • BP: Normal or ↓ with narrow pulse pressure
  • Palpable thrill at the cardiac apex
  • Hyperdynamic, laterally displaced apex beat
  • Normal or ↑ JVP
  • Soft or absent S1
  • Wide, variable splitting of S2
  • S4 may be heard in acute severe MR
  • Holosystolic murmur (chronic MR)
  • Decrescendo early systolic murmur (acute MR)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with shortness of breath on exertion, fatigue, and palpitations. On examination, a pan systolic murmur is heard best at the apex, radiating to the axilla. Echocardiography reveals mitral valve prolapse with significant mitral regurgitation. Which of the following is NOT a typical cause of primary chronic mitral regurgitation?
questions.explanation:
MITRAL REGURGITATION

Etiology

(Options B, C & D ruled out)

Mitral Regurgitation " data-author="" data-hash="8849" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" height="233" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/gSmFC0gAlY0S8WIJwrTM1744309732.png" width="450" />

Pathophysiology

Mitral Regurgitation " data-author="" data-hash="8850" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" height="195" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/b3CWUiFdP7NreV9jpcCk1744309819.png" width="421" />

Clinical features

  • Mild to moderate MR is asymptomatic
  • Severe MR
    • Orthopnea
    • Exertional fatigue
    • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea
    • Ankle oedema
  • Late-onset right-sided heart failure may also occur

questions.text: A 72-year-old male with mitral valve prolapse, chronic atrial fibrillation (CHA2DS2-VASc score of 5), severe mitral regurgitation, and an ejection fraction of 35% presents with occasional palpitations and breathlessness. He also has a history of infective endocarditis. Which of the following statements regarding his management is not true?

options.label: B
options.text: Beta-blockers should be initiated for his palpitations

options.label: C
options.text: Mitral valve repair is preferred over mitral valve replacement

questions.correct_answer: A. Anticoagulation therapy should be avoided
